awd_titl_txt: CAREER:   Properties of Strongly Interacting Matter from Lattice QCD
awd_abstract_narration:
A few microseconds after the Big Bang, the primordial Universe was in a Quark-Gluon Plasma state. Today, this phase of strongly interacting matter can be re-created under extreme conditions of temperatures or densities, like the ones achieved in ultra-relativistic heavy ion collisions currently taking place at the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider (RHIC) and the Large Hadron Collider (LHC). This project will support the experimental programs at RHIC and LHC by calculating observables from first principles and relating them to measurements. The purpose is to advance the understanding of strong interactions by answering unresolved questions related to the nature of the phase transition and the degrees of freedom, which populate the system in the different regions of the phase diagram. The high precision achievable currently in the theoretical calculations allows such a combined effort between theory and experiment for the first time. This project will help train the next generation of students working on the theory of fundamental interactions, both at the undergraduate and graduate levels. Students will be exposed to an international environment and will learn the most advanced theoretical tools. The PI will promote physics to underrepresented minorities through public lectures, seminars and visits to Houston schools.

The goal of this project is to achieve a microscopic understanding of Quark-Gluon Plasma properties. The project will help determine the phase diagram of strongly interacting matter, the degrees of freedom which populate its different regions, the evolution of the system through the QCD crossover transition and its thermodynamic properties in the deconfined phase. The methodology is to calculate relevant observables using numerical simulations from first principles and map them to measurements through phenomenological models. The specific objectives are as follows: determine the temperatures and densities in the QCD phase diagram at which hadrons are formed and relate them to the ones measured in experiment; constrain the existence and position of the critical point, at which the order of the phase transition changes;  establish whether the interaction is strong enough to enable sequential, possibly flavor specific, hadron formation in the QGP. With its zero and finite-density components, the project will yield a coherent theoretical framework for the RHIC and LHC programs from first principles. Besides having immediate applications to heavy ion collisions, the project is expected to have a broader impact on other fields of physics, such as string theory, cosmology and condensed matter.

por.por_cntn:
This project studied the Quark-Gluon Plasma (QGP) and the phase diagram of strongly interacting matter, through the calculation of relevant observables from first principles, their interpretation and their relation to measurements from Heavy Ion Collision experiments (HICs). Ordinary matter turns into the QGP under extreme conditions of temperature and/or density. The reverse transition took place just a few microseconds after the Big Bang: at this point in the evolution of our Universe, the basic building blocks of Nature were formed. Today, HICs at RHIC and the LHC allow to recreate the conditions of the early Universe in the laboratory. The project determined the QCD transition line with the largest precision and coverage in the literature, the QCD equation of state from first principles with the largest coverage in chemical potential and its extension to even larger densities through the holographic approach, the calculation of fluctuations and correlations of conserved quantities from first principle lattice QCD simulations at finite temperature and density, the suggestion of proxies to measure conserved charge correlators in HICs, the stability of the equation of state through machine learning techniques, transport coefficients from holography and many more observables. With its zero and finite-density parts, the project supports the RHIC and LHC programs by providing important quantitative results obtained from first principle simulations.

Intellectual merit: This project, based on first principle calculations, answered a few unresolved questions related to the nature of the QCD phase transition and the degrees of freedom which govern the mechanism of hadronic matter formation. It provided state-of-the-art results for the QCD transition line and equation of state, as well as fluctuations of conserved charges. Besides, it helped to constrain the hadronic spectrum based on the conserved charge content of the corresponding hadrons. It also suggested proxies that the experimental collaboration can measure, to capture the behavior of conserved charge correlations. The calculation of the lattice QCD equation of state is currently the only one in the literature that can reach a value of chemical potential up to 3.5 times the temperature, which is obtained in the low-energy heavy-ion collisions at RHIC. Besides having immediate applications to HICs at RHIC, the LHC and the future FAIR facility, the project has a broader impact on other fields of physics, such as string theory and cosmology. The string-theory based approach of gauge/gravity duality that we used in our research turned out to be a reliable method to describe the system, which allowed us to extend the equation of state to large densities, incorporate the effect of a critical point and first-order phase transition line, and observe the behavior of several transport coefficients across this line. Besides, the equation of state that we obtained can be used to study the cosmological evolution of our universe through the QCD phase transition.

Broader impact. The PI involved her students and postdocs in an international project addressing fundamental questions in high energy, nuclear and astrophysics. The advanced computational techniques used in the project provided them with substantial skills and experiences and prepared them for the next stage in their career. Besides, the PI accomplished the following educational/outreach activities: (1) Worked with her group to present her CAREER research during seminars for high school students and teachers; (2) Promoted diversity in science by mentoring a very diverse group of students, both at the undergraduate and graduate levels; at the same time, promoted women in physics activities at UH by becoming the Women in Physics society's academic advisor; (3) Improved the undergraduate particle physics course, where she included the newest developments in the field and geared the interest of students towards fundamental research; improved the graduate quantum mechanics course to include computational training and group assignments to be solved at the computer; introduced two new courses at UH (Quantum Field Theory II and Quantum Chromodynamics), which were requested by the students.
